items.title: Gelcoat Cracks
items.description:
**What:** Superficial and structural cracks.
**How:** Visually inspect hull sides, deck, and corners.
**Look for:** Fine 'spiderweb' cracks (crazing) vs. deep, straight cracks at load-bearing points.
**Interpretation:** Crazing is often cosmetic but can allow moisture ingress. Deep cracks may indicate structural weakness.

items.title: Osmosis (Blisters)
items.description:
**What:** Signs of osmosis below the waterline.
**How:** Feel the hull. Puncture a suspicious blister to check the fluid and smell.
**Look for:** Hard, fluid-filled blisters. A sour, vinegar-like smell confirms osmosis.
**Interpretation:** Requires costly repairs. Soft blisters are usually only in the antifouling paint.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Requires the boat to be on land. Obtain the owner's consent before puncturing.

items.title: Hull-to-Deck Joint
items.description:
**What:** The integrity of the seam between the hull and deck.
**How:** Look for cracks in the sealant externally. Check for water stains internally.
**Look for:** Cracks, discoloration, or signs of movement in the joint.
**Interpretation:** Can indicate a leak or structural movement that weakens the boat.

items.title: Thru-hulls
items.description:
**What:** Condition of thru-hulls and seacocks below the waterline.
**How:** Open and close all valves. Inspect for corrosion. Check hose clamps.
**Look for:** Green corrosion (verdigris), seized valves, rusty clamps. There should be two hose clamps per hose.
**Interpretation:** Defective seacocks are a critical safety risk and must be replaced.

items.title: Keel (Exterior)
items.description:
**What:** Signs of grounding, movement, or corrosion.
**How:** Inspect the leading edge, bottom, and the joint between the keel and hull.
**Look for:** Deep nicks, scrapes, or a curved crack ('keel smile'). On iron keels, look for rust blisters in the paint.
**Interpretation:** A 'keel smile' indicates structural damage. Rust on an iron keel requires maintenance to prevent progression.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Requires the boat to be on land.

items.title: Keel Bolts (Interior)
items.description:
**What:** The condition of the keel bolts and signs of leaks.
**How:** Inspect the nuts and washers in the bilge.
**Look for:** Rust stains from the nuts or deformed washers.
**Interpretation:** Rust means water ingress. Deformation indicates overload. Both require professional assessment.

items.title: Soft Deck (Delamination)
items.description:
**What:** Water ingress and delamination in the deck core.
**How:** Walk over the deck, especially around fittings. Tap lightly with the handle of a screwdriver.
**Look for:** Soft, spongy areas. A dull, hollow sound ('thud') instead of a sharp ('tap').
**Interpretation:** A dull sound indicates delamination. A serious and costly repair.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Requires a screwdriver or similar to tap with.

items.title: Deck Hardware Leaks
items.description:
**What:** Signs of leaks from fittings mounted on the deck.
**How:** Look inside at the ceiling and bulkheads, under winches, stanchions, windows, etc.
**Look for:** Water stains, dark spots, salt trails, or discolored woodwork.
**Interpretation:** Classic signs of leaks that can lead to delamination or rot.

items.title: Rudder Play
items.description:
**What:** Play in the rudder bearings.
**How:** Take a firm grip on the lower part of the rudder blade. Move it forcefully side-to-side and fore-and-aft.
**Look for:** Noticeable movement or 'clunking' sounds.
**Interpretation:** Significant play indicates worn rudder bearings, a potentially costly repair.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Best performed from land, a dock, or a swim platform.

items.title: Rust Inspection (Steel Hull)
items.description:
**What:** Rust formation on the hull and welds.
**How:** Look for paint blisters. Tap suspicious areas with a hammer. Check the bilge internally.
**Look for:** Blisters in the paint and flaking rust. Standing water inside.
**Interpretation:** Rust under the paint must be ground down and treated to avoid severe corrosion.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Requires a small hammer.

items.title: Rot Inspection (Wood Hull)
items.description:
**What:** Rot in the hull and structure.
**How:** Tap with a plastic mallet and listen for a dull sound. Gently poke suspicious areas with a rounded awl.
**Look for:** Soft wood where the awl sinks in easily, especially near frames and the keel.
**Interpretation:** Soft wood is a sure sign of rot that requires replacement.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Requires a plastic mallet and a rounded awl/screwdriver.

items.title: Corrosion (Aluminum Hull)
items.description:
**What:** Galvanic corrosion and pitting.
**How:** Look for white powder (oxide), especially where water collects or where other metals are attached.
**Look for:** White powder, pits in the metal, and cracks in welds.
**Interpretation:** Corrosion caused by contact with other metals is serious and must be isolated.

items.title: Standing Rigging - Wire & Terminals
items.description:
**What:** Condition of the wire and terminals. Ask about age (recommended lifespan 10-15 years).
**How:** Run a cotton ball along the wire. Inspect the terminals (end fittings) closely.
**Look for:** Snags in the cotton ball (broken strand). Cracks or rust at the terminals.
**Interpretation:** A single broken strand or a crack in a terminal is critical. The wire must be replaced.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** A cotton ball is an effective tool.

items.title: Turnbuckles
items.description:
**What:** The condition of the turnbuckles.
**How:** Look for damage. Check that the threads are not seized. Verify the locking mechanism (cotter pins/rings).
**Look for:** Cracks, bent parts, corrosion, or missing locking pins.
**Interpretation:** A damaged turnbuckle is a serious weakness in the rig and must be replaced.

items.title: Chainplates
items.description:
**What:** Chainplate attachment and signs of leaks.
**How:** Check for deformation externally. Look for water stains on the bulkhead internally.
**Look for:** Bent fittings. Discoloration or moisture damage on the inside.
**Interpretation:** Leaks at the chainplates can lead to serious structural damage (rot/delamination).

items.title: Mast Step & Collar
items.description:
**What:** Signs of compression and corrosion.
**How:** Inspect the deck under the mast step (deck-stepped) or the base in the bilge (keel-stepped).
**Look for:** Cracks in the gelcoat or a sunken area. Corrosion (white powder) on the mast.
**Interpretation:** Compression damage is serious. Corrosion weakens the mast.

items.title: Spreaders
items.description:
**What:** The attachment and angle of the spreaders.
**How:** Look up along the mast. Check the fittings against the mast and the protection on the tips.
**Look for:** Cracks at the root. That they angle slightly upwards. Intact chafe protection.
**Interpretation:** Damage to the fittings or incorrect angle can lead to mast failure.

items.title: Furling System
items.description:
**What:** The condition of the bearings and foil.
**How:** Rotate the furler by hand. Listen for unusual noises. Inspect the foil.
**Look for:** Rumbling or grinding sounds. Dents or corrosion in the foil.
**Interpretation:** Noises indicate worn bearings (costly). A damaged foil can prevent the sail from furling.

items.title: Running Rigging (Halyards & Sheets)
items.description:
**What:** The condition of the ropes.
**How:** Squeeze the ropes and look for wear, especially where they run through blocks/clutches.
**Look for:** Stiff, hard ropes. Obvious wear on the cover.
**Interpretation:** Stiff rope has lost strength. Worn-out running rigging is a significant expense.

items.title: Boom, Gooseneck & Vang
items.description:
**What:** Damage to the boom and its fittings. Function of the vang.
**How:** Inspect the boom for dents/cracks. Wiggle the gooseneck. Check the vang for pressure/leaks.
**Look for:** Excessive play in the gooseneck. Oil leaks from a gas-strut vang.
**Interpretation:** Play or cracks are a safety risk. A faulty vang provides poor sail control.

items.title: Winches
items.description:
**What:** The function and condition of the winches. Ask about service history.
**How:** Turn all winches. Listen for unusual noises. Wiggle the drum.
**Look for:** 'Gritty' or grinding sounds. A lot of sideways play.
**Interpretation:** A stiff winch needs servicing. Noises may mean worn bearings and a larger cost.

items.title: Sailcloth General Condition
items.description:
**What:** The age and wear of the sailcloth.
**How:** Feel the cloth. Hold it up to the light. Look for mildew (black dots).
**Look for:** A soft and 'dead' cloth (blown out) vs. a stiff and 'crispy' one. Thin areas or small holes.
**Interpretation:** Mildew weakens the cloth. A blown-out sail provides poor performance.

items.title: Stitching and Thread
items.description:
**What:** The condition of the thread in the seams.
**How:** Carefully go over seams in corners and along edges. Gently pick at the thread with a fingernail.
**Look for:** Thread that disintegrates or breaks easily.
**Interpretation:** Bad thread is a sure sign of UV damage. The sail needs re-stitching, a significant cost.

items.title: UV Protection on Furling Headsail
items.description:
**What:** The condition of the UV cover and its stitching.
**How:** Inspect the colored strip on the furled sail.
**Look for:** Worn fabric and especially bad stitching.
**Interpretation:** This is the sail's most important protection. If this is poor, the sail itself is likely also sun-damaged.

items.title: Sail Shape
items.description:
**What:** The sail's profile and efficiency.
**How:** Hoist the sail and look at its profile. Observe where the deepest part (the draft) is.
**Look for:** The draft has moved aft. A 'baggy' sail. A fluttering leech.
**Interpretation:** A blown-out sail is inefficient, causing more heel and less forward drive.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Requires a sea trial to assess correctly.

items.title: Batten Pockets & Battens
items.description:
**What:** Wear on batten pockets and damage to battens.
**How:** Inspect the ends of the batten pockets. Remove a batten if possible.
**Look for:** Holes where the batten presses against the cloth. Cracks in the battens.
**Interpretation:** Worn pockets must be repaired to prevent the batten from chafing a hole in the sail.

items.title: Sail Hardware
items.description:
**What:** The condition of slides, slugs, and attachment points in the corners.
**How:** Inspect all plastic and metal parts attached to the sail.
**Look for:** Cracks in plastic. Deformation in pressed rings. Corrosion.
**Interpretation:** Broken hardware can render the sail unusable until repaired.

items.title: Reefing Points
items.description:
**What:** The reinforcements for the reefing points in the mainsail.
**How:** Find the cringles or webbing loops used for reefing. Inspect the surrounding area.
**Look for:** Signs of cringles tearing out. Loose or damaged stitching.
**Interpretation:** These points are subjected to enormous forces. Damage here is serious.

items.title: Downwind Sails (Spinnaker / Gennaker)
items.description:
**What:** The condition of light-wind sails.
**How:** Ask to see the sails laid out. Hold the cloth up to the light.
**Look for:** Small tears, holes, and patches.
**Interpretation:** Minor damage is common, but many repairs can indicate a hard life.

items.title: Sail Covers / Lazy Bag
items.description:
**What:** The condition of the sail protection.
**How:** Check seams, zippers, and fasteners.
**Look for:** Worn and UV-damaged fabric and thread.
**Interpretation:** Poor protection indicates the sail may have suffered more sun damage than necessary.

items.title: Headliner Condition
items.description:
**What:** Signs of leaks from the deck.
**How:** Look for discoloration or mold on the ceiling. Press gently upwards, especially around hatches/fittings.
**Look for:** Water stains, dark spots, or a sagging headliner. Soft areas.
**Interpretation:** A soft ceiling is a serious sign of a leak and delamination of the deck above.

items.title: Bulkhead Bonding (Structure)
items.description:
**What:** Structural integrity.
**How:** Inspect where the bulkheads (walls) are attached to the hull sides.
**Look for:** Cracks in the 'tabbing' (fiberglass/adhesive joint). Water stains running down the bulkheads.
**Interpretation:** Cracks suggest the hull is flexing too much, a potential structural weakness.

items.title: Bilge Condition
items.description:
**What:** Leaks and general maintenance.
**How:** Lift the floorboards at the lowest point. Check for water, oil, or debris.
**Look for:** Water in the bilge. Use a paper towel to check if it's saltwater or freshwater.
**Interpretation:** The source of any water must be identified. Saltwater is often the most serious.

items.title: Moisture behind Woodwork & Panels
items.description:
**What:** Hidden leaks.
**How:** Shine a flashlight into lockers and behind panels. Use your nose.
**Look for:** Dark, discolored wood. A pungent, musty smell.
**Interpretation:** Strong warning signs of persistent moisture problems.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Requires a good flashlight.

items.title: Leaks & Function - Windows & Hatches
items.description:
**What:** Sealing and mechanical function.
**How:** Look for water stains on the inside and test the rubber gaskets. Open, close, and lock all hatches/windows.
**Look for:** Traces of leaks. Cracked gaskets. Stiff or defective mechanism.
**Interpretation:** Leaks can cause a lot of damage. A defective hatch is a safety and cost risk.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Test with a water hose (with owner's consent) to confirm leaks.

items.title: Floorboards & Sole Structure
items.description:
**What:** Rot in the underlying floor structure.
**How:** Walk systematically through the boat and step firmly on the floorboards (sole).
**Look for:** Soft, flexing, or 'spongy' areas.
**Interpretation:** Often indicates that the support structure has rotted due to a leak.

items.title: General Odor in the Boat
items.description:
**What:** Indications of underlying problems.
**How:** Use your nose actively as soon as you come aboard.
**Look for:** A musty smell (moisture), diesel smell (leak), or sewage smell (holding tank problem).
**Interpretation:** Don't ignore what your nose is telling you.

items.title: Cushions & Mattresses
items.description:
**What:** Signs of moisture and poor ventilation.
**How:** Lift up cushions and mattresses. Look at and smell the underside.
**Look for:** Black dots (mildew) or damp foam.
**Interpretation:** A clear sign of either a condensation problem or a direct leak.

items.title: Ventilation
items.description:
**What:** The boat's ability to air out moisture and avoid condensation.
**How:** Look for dedicated air vents (dorades, mushroom vents, fans) in addition to hatches.
**Look for:** The number and placement of vents. Are they open and functional?
**Interpretation:** Poor ventilation is the main cause of mildew and a poor indoor climate.

items.title: Engine Oil - Level & Color
items.description:
**What:** Signs of water in the oil or poor maintenance.
**How:** Check the dipstick and the inside of the oil filler cap before a cold start.
**Look for:** Oil level. Gray/milky oil ('mayonnaise'). Thick, tar-like oil.
**Interpretation:** Gray oil means water ingress - very serious. Tar-like oil suggests neglected service.

items.title: General Condition - Rust & Cleanliness
items.description:
**What:** General impression of maintenance.
**How:** Assess cleanliness. Look for surface rust and freshly painted areas.
**Look for:** A clean engine vs. one covered in oil/soot. Deep, flaking rust. Paint hiding problems.
**Interpretation:** A well-maintained engine is often a sign of a conscientious owner.

items.title: Oil Leaks
items.description:
**What:** Active oil leaks.
**How:** Systematically shine a light down the engine block. Check the bilge under the engine.
**Look for:** Fresh, wet oil spots. A 'sweaty' engine might be okay, but clear drips are not.
**Interpretation:** Leaks must be located and repaired.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Requires a good flashlight.

items.title: Belts & Pulleys
items.description:
**What:** The condition and tension of drive belts (e.g., for alternator, water pump).
**How:** Look for cracks. Squeeze the belt to check its tension (approx. 1 cm / 0.5 inch give).
**Look for:** Cracks in the rubber. Black dust around the pulleys.
**Interpretation:** Cracks or a loose belt require immediate replacement.

items.title: Cooling Hoses & Clamps
items.description:
**What:** Condition of raw water and freshwater hoses.
**How:** Squeeze the hoses. Look for signs of leaks (salt crystals, corrosion) at the clamps.
**Look for:** Soft, spongy, or bulging hoses.
**Interpretation:** Bad hoses can collapse and cause overheating.

items.title: Exhaust Manifold & Riser
items.description:
**What:** Signs of rust-through, which can let water into the engine.
**How:** Look for rust stains on the outside, especially at the joint between the manifold and riser.
**Look for:** Clear traces of rusty water.
**Interpretation:** An internal leak here is critical and costly. Often needs replacement after 10-15 years.

items.title: Cold Start & Exhaust Smoke Color
items.description:
**What:** The engine's health based on its exhaust.
**How:** Observe the exhaust smoke right after a cold start.
**Look for:** Blue smoke (oil consumption), thick white smoke (water/head gasket), or black smoke (poor combustion).
**Interpretation:** The color of the smoke is an important diagnostic indicator of the engine's internal condition.

items.title: Cooling Water Flow
items.description:
**What:** The efficiency of the raw water pump.
**How:** Look at the cooling water outlet on the hull side or the 'telltale' stream immediately after starting the engine.
**Look for:** A steady, strong stream of water.
**Interpretation:** A weak or 'spitting' stream indicates a worn impeller or clogged intake.

items.title: Engine Mounts
items.description:
**What:** The condition of the engine mounts' rubber and metal.
**How:** Look for cracks in the rubber. Observe the engine when it's put into gear.
**Look for:** Cracks, compressed rubber. Excessive movement/clunking when shifting gears.
**Interpretation:** Worn mounts cause vibrations and can damage the shaft/drive.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Requires a sea trial for a full check.

items.title: Saildrive - Diaphragm
items.description:
**What:** Age and condition of the rubber diaphragm between the drive and the hull.
**How:** Ask the owner for the diaphragm's age and documentation of replacement. Inspect visible parts for cracks.
**Look for:** That the diaphragm is within its replacement interval (typically 7-10 years).
**Interpretation:** An old diaphragm is a critical safety risk for water ingress.

items.title: Shaft Seal (Stuffing Box)
items.description:
**What:** Leakage from the shaft seal where the propeller shaft enters the boat.
**How:** Inspect where the propeller shaft enters the boat.
**Look for:** Drips from the seal. A traditional stuffing box may drip slightly when running, but should be tight when stationary. A dripless seal should be completely dry.
**Interpretation:** Excessive leakage requires adjustment or replacement.

items.title: Tilt/Trim System (Outboard)
items.description:
**What:** Function and condition of the engine's tilt and trim mechanism.
**How:** Run the engine all the way up and down using the buttons. Look for oil leaks from the cylinders.
**Look for:** Jerky movement, unusual noises, or leaks of hydraulic fluid.
**Interpretation:** Repairs to the hydraulic system can be costly.

items.title: Propeller & Skeg (Outboard)
items.description:
**What:** Damage to the propeller and the protective fin (skeg) below it.
**How:** Inspect the propeller blades for nicks and deformation. Check if the skeg is straight and without major damage.
**Look for:** Nicks, bent blades, fishing line around the shaft. A cracked or broken skeg.
**Interpretation:** A damaged propeller causes vibration and poor performance. A damaged skeg suggests a grounding.

items.title: Steering (Outboard)
items.description:
**What:** Play and friction in the engine's steering system.
**How:** Manually turn the engine from side to side (when on land). Turn the wheel and feel for play.
**Look for:** Stiffness, unusual noises, or 'dead play' in the steering.
**Interpretation:** Stiff steering can be caused by old cables or poor lubrication and can be a safety hazard.

items.title: Jet Drive - Impeller & Wear Ring
items.description:
**What:** Damage and wear in the jet pump that reduces performance.
**How:** Shine a light into the intake grate and outlet nozzle. Look for nicks, bent blades on the impeller, and clearance between the impeller and the wear ring.
**Interpretation:** Damage to the impeller or excessive clearance to the wear ring leads to cavitation and loss of thrust.

items.title: Battery Bank - Age & Condition
items.description:
**What:** The health, age, and safety of the batteries.
**How:** Look for corrosion, bulging sides, and the production date. Check that they are securely fastened.
**Look for:** White/green powder on the terminals. Bulging sides. That the batteries are less than 7 years old.
**Interpretation:** Bulging batteries are ruined. Loose batteries are dangerous in rough seas.

items.title: Wiring & Connections
items.description:
**What:** The quality of the electrical installation.
**How:** Look behind panels and in the engine room. Assess the tidiness and quality of connections.
**Look for:** A 'rat's nest' of unlabeled cables. Use of electrical tape or household-style terminal blocks.
**Interpretation:** Poor wiring is a serious fire hazard and indicates amateur work.

items.title: Main Switches
items.description:
**What:** The condition of the main switches.
**How:** Operate the switches. Feel them after they have been under load (engine start/shore power).
**Look for:** A firm 'click' feel. That the switches do not get hot.
**Interpretation:** A hot switch indicates a bad connection and a fire hazard.

items.title: Charging Voltage from Alternator
items.description:
**What:** The function of the alternator.
**How:** Measure the voltage at the battery terminals while the engine is running at increased RPM (approx. 1500 RPM).
**Look for:** A charging voltage between 14.2V and 14.8V.
**Interpretation:** Voltage below 14V means poor charging. Above 15V can destroy the batteries.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Requires a multimeter.

items.title: Shore Power & RCD/GFCI
items.description:
**What:** The safety of the shore power system.
**How:** Inspect the inlet for signs of overheating. Press the test button on the RCD/GFCI breaker onboard.
**Look for:** Discolored/melted plastic on the inlet. That the power cuts off immediately when tested.
**Interpretation:** A non-functioning RCD/GFCI is a life-threatening defect.

items.title: Switch & Fuse Panel
items.description:
**What:** The function of all switches and equipment.
**How:** Systematically turn on all switches and verify that lights, pumps, etc., are working.
**Look for:** Clear labeling of switches. Signs of overheating.
**Interpretation:** Provides a good overview of the condition of the electrical equipment.

items.title: Navigation Lights
items.description:
**What:** Function of all navigation lights.
**How:** Test all lights separately (port, starboard, stern, steaming, masthead).
**Look for:** That the correct color lights up in the correct place and that they are intact.
**Interpretation:** Faults can be due to a bulb, corrosion, or a wiring break.

items.title: Anodes (Sacrificial Zincs)
items.description:
**What:** The condition and function of the anodes.
**How:** Find all sacrificial anodes on the drive, shaft, rudder, etc.
**Look for:** That they are about 50% depleted. If they look brand new after a season, they have poor contact.
**Interpretation:** A 'perfect' anode is not protecting the boat. Should be replaced annually.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Requires the boat to be on land.

items.title: Freshwater System (Pump & Quality)
items.description:
**What:** Leaks in the system and water quality.
**How:** Pour a glass of water, smell and taste it. Then listen to the pump with all faucets closed.
**Look for:** A sour or stale smell in the water. The pump cycling periodically without water being used.
**Interpretation:** Periodic pumping indicates a leak. Poor water quality requires cleaning the tank/hoses.

items.title: Holding Tank Hoses - Odor
items.description:
**What:** If odor is permeating through the sanitation hoses.
**How:** Place a warm, damp cloth around a sanitation hose for a few minutes. Smell the cloth.
**Look for:** A distinct sewage smell on the cloth.
**Interpretation:** Odor means the hoses are permeated and must be replaced. An unpleasant and costly job.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Requires a warm, damp cloth.

items.title: Toilet - Operation & Leaks
items.description:
**What:** The toilet's pump function and seals.
**How:** Operate the pump (manual/electric). Look around the base and connections.
**Look for:** Smooth pump operation. Signs of leaks (moisture or salt crystals).
**Interpretation:** Leaks from the sanitation system are unhygienic and must be fixed.

items.title: Water Heater
items.description:
**What:** The heater's function on engine heat and shore power.
**How:** Check for hot water after a sea trial (engine heat) and when connected to shore power (230V/120V).
**Look for:** That the water gets hot in both cases. Leaks from the heater itself.
**Interpretation:** Indicates the condition of both the heater and the cooling/electrical system.

items.title: Diesel Heater
items.description:
**What:** The function of the diesel-fired forced-air heater.
**How:** Start the heater. Listen to the fans and fuel pump. Observe the exhaust outlet outside.
**Look for:** Unusual noises. Persistent white or black smoke after the startup phase.
**Interpretation:** Smoke indicates a need for service (cleaning/glow plug).

items.title: Sink Drainage
items.description:
**What:** If the drains are clogged.
**How:** Fill the sinks with water and see how quickly it drains.
**Look for:** Slow drainage.
**Interpretation:** Slow drainage suggests partially clogged hoses or thru-hulls.

items.title: Wheel Steering - Play & Friction
items.description:
**What:** Wear in the steering system.
**How:** Gently move the wheel to check for 'dead play'. Turn from lock to lock to feel for resistance.
**Look for:** A distinct 'clunk' or a lot of dead play. Stiff or uneven spots.
**Interpretation:** Indicates wear in the pedestal, wires, or rudder bearings.

items.title: Steering Cables & Sheaves (Wire)
items.description:
**What:** Condition of steering cables and sheaves.
**How:** Follow the wire from the pedestal to the rudder quadrant. Run a cloth along the wire. Check that the sheaves rotate freely.
**Look for:** Rust or broken strands ('hooks'). Slack cables. Stiff sheaves.
**Interpretation:** Damaged wire or stiff sheaves are a safety risk.

items.title: Rudder Quadrant / Tiller Arm
items.description:
**What:** Cracks or play in the rudder quadrant.
**How:** Visually inspect the metal. Wiggle the quadrant to feel for play against the rudder stock.
**Look for:** Cracks, especially around the attachment to the rudder stock. Loose bolts.
**Interpretation:** Cracks in this critical point can lead to a total loss of steering.

items.title: Rudder Bearings - Internal Check
items.description:
**What:** Play in the upper rudder bearing.
**How:** One person moves the rudder outside, while another looks/listens at the top of the rudder stock inside.
**Look for:** Visible movement of the stock relative to the bearing. 'Clunking' sounds.
**Interpretation:** The best way to confirm play in the upper bearing.

items.title: Emergency Tiller - Function Test
items.description:
**What:** If the emergency steering is functional.
**How:** Find the emergency tiller and try to fit it onto the top of the rudder stock.
**Look for:** That it fits easily and securely in place.
**Interpretation:** Many emergency solutions are only theoretical. Check that it works in practice.

items.title: Hydraulic Steering
items.description:
**What:** Leaks or air in the hydraulic system.
**How:** Check the oil level in the reservoir. Look for oil spills on the steering cylinder. Turn the wheel from lock to lock.
**Look for:** Low oil level. Signs of leakage. A soft or 'spongy' feel in the wheel.
**Interpretation:** Spongy steering means air in the system, likely from a leak.

items.title: Tiller
items.description:
**What:** Damage to the tiller.
**How:** Inspect for cracks (wood/metal). Wiggle it hard to check the fitting.
**Look for:** Cracks, delamination (wood), or bends. Play in the fitting to the rudder stock.
**Interpretation:** A weak tiller is a safety risk.

items.title: Autopilot - Drive Unit
items.description:
**What:** The condition of the autopilot's motor/pump.
**How:** Engage the autopilot. Listen to the drive unit as it works. Look for leaks (hydraulic).
**Look for:** Unusually loud noise (grinding, humming).
**Interpretation:** Noise can indicate wear. Check that it steers correctly during the sea trial.

items.title: Fire Extinguishers
items.description:
**What:** The condition and age of the extinguishers.
**How:** Find all extinguishers. Check the pressure gauge and the production/service date.
**Look for:** The needle is in the green zone. They are less than 10 years old (dry powder).
**Interpretation:** An extinguisher without pressure or that is too old is useless.

items.title: Bilge Pumps
items.description:
**What:** The function of the bilge pumps.
**How:** Test the electric pump with the manual switch. Lift the float switch to test the automatic function. Test the manual pump with its handle.
**Look for:** That the pumps start and pump water effectively.
**Interpretation:** Critical safety equipment that must function flawlessly.

items.title: LPG/Gas System
items.description:
**What:** The age of the gas hose and the system's integrity.
**How:** Check the date on the hose. Perform a leak test by pressurizing and waiting for 5 minutes.
**Look for:** The hose is less than 5 years old. The pressure holds steady.
**Interpretation:** A gas leak is extremely dangerous. Older hoses should be replaced regardless.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Requires soapy water or leak detection spray to find small leaks.

items.title: Stanchions & Lifelines
items.description:
**What:** The strength of the stanchion bases.
**How:** Vigorously wiggle each individual stanchion.
**Look for:** Movement at the base of the stanchions.
**Interpretation:** Movement is a serious sign of water ingress and delamination in the deck.

items.title: Anchor & Windlass
items.description:
**What:** The function of the windlass.
**How:** Test that the windlass runs the chain/rode smoothly both out and in.
**Look for:** Uneven or strained sounds from the motor. That the anchor is securely stowed.
**Interpretation:** A windlass that doesn't work when you need it is a major problem.

items.title: Liferaft - Service Date
items.description:
**What:** If the liferaft has a valid service.
**How:** Find the service sticker on the raft's container.
**Look for:** The date of the last certified service.
**Interpretation:** An out-of-date raft represents a significant cost for a new service.

items.title: Flares & Pyrotechnics - Expiry Date
items.description:
**What:** The validity of the pyrotechnic equipment.
**How:** Go through all flares, rockets, and smoke signals.
**Look for:** The expiry date on each unit.
**Interpretation:** Expired equipment is unreliable and must be replaced.

items.title: Service Records & Receipts
items.description:
**What:** Documentation of maintenance and major work.
**How:** Ask to see a binder with receipts and documentation.
**Look for:** Service history for the engine, rigging, saildrive diaphragm, sails, etc.
**Interpretation:** A good history is a strong positive sign. Lack of history increases your risk.

items.title: Registration Papers (Ownership, CE-mark)
items.description:
**What:** That the boat's papers are in order and ownership is correct.
**How:** Compare the hull number (HIN/CIN) with the papers. Look for a CE mark (required after 1998).
**Look for:** Consistency between papers and the boat. That the seller is the registered owner. Check for liens.
**Interpretation:** Critical for a legal and safe transaction.

items.title: Manuals & Instruction Books
items.description:
**What:** The presence of technical documentation.
**How:** Ask for the binder with manuals for the engine, electronics, etc.
**Look for:** A complete and tidy collection.
**Interpretation:** A sign of a conscientious owner. Invaluable for future maintenance.

items.title: Sea Trial
items.description:
**What:** Performance and function under real load.
**How:** Warm up the engine, go to full throttle for a few minutes. Hoist the sails and sail on different points of sail. Engage the autopilot.
**Look for:** The engine reaches max RPM without overheating. The boat is balanced on the helm. The autopilot holds a steady course.
**Interpretation:** The only way to assess the engine, rig, and sails under real load.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** This is the most important item in the entire check. Allow plenty of time.

items.title: Questions for the Owner
items.description:
**What:** The owner's knowledge and insight about the boat.
**How:** Ask open-ended questions about its history, known faults, damages, and why they are selling.
**Look for:** Consistent and credible answers.
**Interpretation:** Can provide valuable insight you won't find elsewhere.

items.title: Mooring Lines & Fenders
items.description:
**What:** The condition of ropes and fenders.
**How:** Squeeze the ropes. Look for chafe. Check that the fenders hold air.
**Look for:** Soft and supple ropes. Hard, stiff ropes are old and weak.
**Interpretation:** A complete set of new mooring lines is a significant expense.

items.title: VHF Radio
items.description:
**What:** The VHF's basic function.
**How:** Turn it on, listen for activity to confirm reception. Ask if an MMSI is programmed.
**Look for:** A clear display and sound. Functional squelch.
**Interpretation:** The MMSI must be re-registered to the new owner. Confirms that important safety equipment works.

items.title: Chartplotter / GPS
items.description:
**What:** The chartplotter's function and the age of the charts.
**How:** Turn it on. Check startup time and if it gets a satellite lock. Test zoom/pan. Ask about the chart's age.
**Look for:** Moisture damage in the screen. Slow response.
**Interpretation:** Updating chart cards can be costly.

items.title: Galley Stove
items.description:
**What:** The stove's function and safety.
**How:** Light all burners and the oven, if applicable. Test the gimbal by moving it side to side.
**Look for:** A steady, blue flame. Free movement in the gimbals.
**Interpretation:** A yellow/sooty flame requires service. A seized gimbal is a safety hazard.

items.title: Refrigerator / Cooler
items.description:
**What:** The compressor's function and cooling ability.
**How:** Turn it on and let it run for 15-20 minutes. Listen to see if the compressor runs continuously or cycles.
**Look for:** That it gets cold. That the compressor cycles on and off.
**Interpretation:** A compressor that never stops will drain the batteries quickly.

items.title: Dinghy & Outboard
items.description:
**What:** The condition of the dinghy and its outboard motor.
**How:** Look for patches on the dinghy, check the seams. Start the motor and look for the cooling water telltale stream.
**Look for:** Many repairs on the dinghy. That the engine starts easily and has a steady water stream.
**Interpretation:** A weak telltale stream means the impeller needs replacing. Failing seams are a common problem.
ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Testing the motor requires a barrel of water or a test run.
